page.title: 09Wyke Hall
page.content: Wyke Hall is thought to have been in existence in the time of Edward 111 as the home of Richard de Wyke. Parts of the Hall definitly date from Tudor times when it was the residence of Cressbyne de Wyke, an official of the Manor. The panelling in the old hall and dining room is Tudor. There is a fireplace dated 1611 and the east wall still retains what are thought to be 17 century mullioned windows. One of the later occupants, John Mortimer, left two heraldic shields within one of the rooms. It is believed that in the Hall may, in pre-reformation times have been a monastery and that the lake which was larger then, was the monks fish pond. Nowadays, the Hall has been divided into private flats.
